p: It would seem that the insect repellency of the essential oil of Ruta chalepensis is due to its major compound, 2-undecanone (64.35%). Indeed, in 2007, in the United States of America, the Environmental Protection Agency approved the repellant BioUD®, in which the active compound is 2-undecanone (7.75%) isolated from wild tomatoes ( Lycopersicon hirsutum Dunal f. glabratum C. H. Müll). BioUD® was more effective against mosquitos ( Aedes aegypti L. and Aedes albopictus Skuse) and the American dog tick ( Dermacentor variabilis Say.) than the commercial repellant DEET (N, N diethyl-m-toluamide), mostly used against arthropods [ 31], thus proving the strong repellent effect of 2-undecanone.
